body:
@shanthoosh and I discussed with Radai and Sean offline. It is not clear that this patch can will fix the issue described in LIKAFKA-20228 because we don't know the root cause of that issue yet. It also seems hacky to reinstantiate kafka producer to address issue -- if this can fix anything then kafka producer should reinitialize something internally and retry without exposing failure to the user. 

I will help look into the kafka producer issue. Let's try to figure out the root cause of that issue before having any hotfix in Samza to reinstantiate producer upon exception.

@lindong28 @shanthoosh, regardless of the cause for that specific exception, I think it's still possible that a KafkaProducer fails due to a temporary broker-side issue (e.g. message send timeout due to temporary broker availability). IIRC, timeouts are considered fatal for the producer and are not recoverable. In this case, we still want to recreate the producer and retry the send instead of failing the container. Please correct me if I'm misunderstanding Kafka behavior.

@shanthoosh Tested with cd BASE_LIB_DIR && exec $JAVA $JAVA_OPTS -cp $CLASSPATH and found this breaks control-dev & control-yarn, since they build bash arguments expecting this execution of JAVA from a specific path. We use relative path in those scripts for certs, other config files.

Changing the execution directory for Java entails a larger refactoring

@prateekm @shanthoosh The temporarily broker side (or network-related) issue should not cause persistent failure on producer side. It may cause failure for a given request but KafkaProducer is expected to still function correctly for the future request after the broker side issue goes away.

After going through the code in `org.apache.samza.checkpoint.kafka.KafkaCheckpointManager.java` and `com.linkedin.samza.system.kafka.SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer`, it appears that `SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer` will record the first produce failure exception in `fatalException` which causes all future calls of `send()` to fail with this exception. It does not make sense to make all `send()` to fail after one `send()` failure. Maybe we should fix this behavior by e.g. sending `fatalException = null` after this exception has been exposed to caller (e.g. `KafkaCheckpointManager` ).

@lindong28 Thanks for sharing your feedback. The ratoinale behind recreating KafkaSystemProducer was based upon the recommendation I received from few members of kafka team. It was claimed that some SSL excpetions in producer  are irrecoverable and it will be better to retry  by recreating the producer instance from samza side. 

Now if that is unnecessary and existing SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer implementation throws up on the first occurrence of any kafka exceptions. Do you think it will be useful to add configurable, fixed retries on kafka exceptions in `SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer` implementation rather than failing repeatedly after first occurrence of exception. By this we can get the following benefits: 

1. First occurrence of exception in the `SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer` wouldn't make the `SamzaLiKafkaSystemProducer` instance unusable.
2. Retries would be closer to the kafka i/o layer where we can decide whether to retry on specific retriable exceptions thrown by kafka. 

What do you think?
@shanthoosh @lindong28 @dnishimura Let's discuss offline, this discussion is getting too long for a PR.
@shanthoosh It probably makes sense to add Java comment with reference to SAMZA-1393 and say that the hotfix added in this PR can be removed after SAMZA-1393 is completed.

Made the following changes: 

* Separated input regex monitoring logic into InputStreamRegexMonitor
* Added separate test cases
* Added logic to get regexes from rewriters' configs. In case of multiple rewriters for the same system, the logic combines those regexes into one using a logical OR.
* Addressed other comments regarding log-messages, etc.

A very high-level comment: Should the SET be restricted to shell ? It would be good to support it in the samza sql file as well so that users could add their configs in samza.sql file as well.

@rmatharu Can you clarify what the actual issue was? This will prevent concurrent modifications but will not keep the state consistent across multiple users of this class. Would it be better to make this non-static and add a getter instead?

MockStorageEngine has a static list of incomingMessageEnvelopes, which was a non thread-safe ArrayList.
However in case of parallel restore (recent change), this needs to be a thread-safe list.
This causes a StorageRecoveryTool test to be flaky.

I have a separate PR in flight that will streamline these tests.
cc @vjagadish1989 for review

Example exception (org.apache.samza.storage.TestStorageRecovery.testStorageEngineReceivedAllValues):

```

Even though the current PR is functionally correct, I wonder if it'll be cleaner to take a different approach to the implementation?..

1. Intents to (re)set a startpoint for a given ssp are recorded in the metadata store
2. Each task writes back to the store when it's acknowledged processing the intent
 
Subsequent reads on the startpointManager reconcile [1] and [2] when constructing the startpoint. 

Also, this will potentially eliminate read-modify-write methods on the startpointManager.

> Even though the current PR is functionally correct, I wonder if it'll be cleaner to take a different approach to the implementation?..
> 
>     1. Intents to (re)set a startpoint for a given ssp are recorded in the metadata store
> 
>     2. Each task writes back to the store when it's acknowledged processing the intent
> 
> 
> Subsequent reads on the startpointManager reconcile [1] and [2] when constructing the startpoint.
> 
> Also, this will potentially eliminate read-modify-write methods on the startpointManager.

Would your suggestion treat the metadata store more like a log of actions than a KV store? Would the StartpointManager need to read a few different entries to figure out if something needs to be done?

@atoomula Yes we could support SET in the samza sql file in the next PR. Just one logic we need to clarify: shall the configs in the sql file be kept effective even after a samza.sql is executed, or shall the previous shell settings be restored after a sql file being executed?

I think this warrants a one pager describing what the behavior of set in Samza sql file would be and its interaction with the regular config properties.

@dnishimura Linkedin's adaptation of samza uses Guava 23.0 while, OSS has been compiled with Guava 17.0, this is causing conflicts for "Objects.toStringHelper" util in several classes  which was present in 17.0 but is absent is 23.0
In your current or later patches can you please address this?

@Sanil15 
I am assigned to work on the save point feature. So I will work on addressing your concern.

@xinyuiscool @sborya 
Please take a look when you have a chance.
@jagadish-v0 I'll commit this for now to unblock @rmatharu. He'll address any other feedback you have in a follow up PR.

@dnishimura :  I discussed offline with @cameronlee314 . Due to these suggestions in reviews, it will be better, if I take over this PR and not bother you during vacation :). Feel free to close this PR.
@Sanil15 Why are these in core?

@prateekm consumer/producer for InMemorySystem is in core and descriptors were in test, hence we need this to be in core. In addition to that these descriptors now do not tightly couple with TestRunner
@xinyuiscool will do

> @prateekm consumer/producer for InMemorySystem is in core and descriptors were in test, hence we need this to be in core. In addition to that these descriptors now do not tightly couple with TestRunner

In general, users should not have to depend on samza-core. Descriptors are part of the API. Maybe we could have a separate module called samza-in-memory (or something like that), similar to how the kafka descriptors are in samza-kafka.

@Sanil15 @bharathkk Is InMemorySystem meant to be used for anything other than tests? If not, both system and descriptors should be in test. If yes, please explain why and see Cameron's suggestion above. At least the descriptors should be in samza-api.
I remember samza-inmemory used to exist in samza-test and then the consumer/producer were moved to core @bharathkk do you remember why this was done.

@xinyuiscool @sborya 
Please take a look when you have a chance.
Agree with @cameronlee314. The descriptors should go to api. THe consumer/producer will be better if kept inside core. that'll be a nice separation.
@Sanil15 @xinyuiscool why are we doing this though? Why make these non-test in the first place? Are you using this for something?

@xinyuiscool Even for the use cases you mentioned, I'm not sure if there are non-test/demo uses cases for creating streams with small deterministic in-memory collections?

I'm OK with moving them to API, but it's not sufficient to just change package names. We should clearly document what capabilities these "in memory streams" provide, and what can/should they be used for. E.g., if they're primarily meant for dev environments, testing and demo apps, I don't want users accidentally using them in place of actual streams expecting them to work.

This is actually for usability, I believe. With this api, I can quickly create a samza pipeline and test it out some logic without setting up the heavy lifting kafka or other streams. In another word, it's good for prototyping. There is some special use case that might require injecting some fixed data set too, e.g. Beam Impulse can use this to inject the binary array to init the following operators to read the read data source, which today we create a very simple factory which does what similar things.

I agree we need good documentation for this and clean it up so it can be user-facing. I do see this is an opportunity to make this Inmemory api better and have no coupling with samza test runner.

@xinyuiscool Agree that this helps with prototyping. I think we're on the same page regarding goals. Would you mind creating tickets for tracking documentation and API changes (if necessary) for making this a public API? Will @Sanil15 be working on them? I'd prefer those changes to go in first, or at least along with the PR to move these classes from samza-test to samza-api.
@prateekm : Refactor the LocalContainerRunner as discussed. Please take a look. Thx!

Agreed @xinyuiscool 
 
@prateekm 
- Descriptors have java docs 
- I guess producer/consumer needs documentation (@bharathkk Please correct me if I am wrong) 
- General utility to produce and consume to streams in in-memory are needed

@Sanil15 Existence of javadocs is not enough. "We should clearly document what capabilities these "in memory streams" provide, and what can/should they be used for. E.g., if they're primarily meant for dev environments, testing and demo apps, I don't want users accidentally using them in place of actual streams expecting them to work."
@prateekm Can you take a look since you have more context.

Just a suggestion to save any additional work. I'm :ok: with either way... let me know what you think. Thanks!
